en: Interview with Mike Aday, 2019-10-14

Interview with Mike Aday, archivist for the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Aday discusses the day of the fire from the vantage point of someone outside the city. He recounts the fear of the day as well as the damage done to the city of Gatlinburg and surrounding area. He provides insight into academic research areas that have opened up after the wildfire. This is a representative quote from the interview: "I think it's important that we look at the fire history of this area and look at the human impact that has created these fire events. This isn't a one off."

Bibliographic Description in MODS
Interview with Mike Aday, 2019-10-14
Interview Questions
Can you tell us some of your background in Gatlinburg?
Can you tell us when you first knew there was a fire?
Can you tell us where the Twin Creeks Science Center is?
Were any of your colleagues talking about the fire?
On the morning of the fire, where were you?
Can you tell us the route you took going into Gatlinburg and what you saw?
When you got to the Visitor's Center, did you see any smoke?
What transpired after going to the science center?
Where was the orange glow that you described?
What were your emotions heading towards the science center?
Everyone seemed content to wait, what happend next?
You didn't have any issues leaving the science center?
When you arrived back at the Visitor's Center, did it feel safer?
Can you describe what was going on at the Visitor's Center (corrected to Park Headquarters located behind Visitor's Center)?
Did it seem coordinated?
How long were you at headquarters?
Had you noticed any changes in the wind or smoke at this point?
What else did you do that day?
Did Gatlinburg catching on fire surprise you?
What was it like coming back to Park Headquarters after the fire?
When you left Park Headquarters going towards Gatlinburg, what did you see?
As you're driving past Mynatt Park and see the damage, what is your emotional reaction?
What was the emotional impact of the entire event?
What was the emotional impact of the entire event?
Did you notice what effect the fire had on the community?
Did anything good or surprising come out of this?
Did this open any opportunites for the scientific community to do research?
Have you thought about any provisions you would make if this happened again?
Is there anything else you would like to add?
Do you agree that this is not a one off event, that it can happen again?
